He was like a human dragon and elephant, like a lion king, like a bull king, like a well-bred horse, the most supreme among humans, like a white lotus flower, like a still pool, like a majestic mountain dwelling in the great ocean, endowed with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics, like a marvelous golden banner whose form and color pervaded everywhere, also like the bright sun with a thousand rays shining, like the full moon surrounded by stars.

He followed with his ministers, calmly mindful, his faculties tranquil, with his right shoulder bared, his robes in order, his body bent in respect, his palms joined, he went to where the World-Honored One was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, scattered excellent flowers, and burned various famous incenses.

At that time, King Prasenajit rose from his seat, and with his usual dignified manner, joined his palms towards the Buddha and said these words:
I only wish that the Great Teacher

would enlighten me, teach me well, and explain the Dharma for a ruler, so that I may always experience peace and happiness in the present, and after my life ends, I will be born in the heavens, and up to the continuous good mind of enlightenment.

Excellent!
You should listen single-mindedly, for this is extremely rare!
Who can ask questions and seek superior provisions? You should follow the Dharma and eliminate evil things.
Why is this?
Great King!

If a king or minister abandons good dharmas and practices evil dharmas, in this present life people will despise him and dare not associate with him, all giving rise to doubt. He will always have bad dreams, have many enemies, and later give rise to regret. After death, he will fall into hell.
Great King!

If a king or minister distances himself from evil dharmas and cultivates good dharmas, in this present life people will look up to him, all coming to associate with him without giving rise to doubt. He will always have good dreams, be able to eliminate enemies, and have no further regrets. After death, he will be reborn in the heavens, up to attaining enlightenment and realizing true and eternal bliss.
Great King!
It is like parents, who love their children and always wish for their well-being, preventing them from doing evil and encouraging them to do good deeds.
Great King!

Those who become heavenly kings should also be like this, bestowing kindness and nurturing all officials up to the people of the country and servants with the four means of gathering disciples: giving, kind speech, beneficial action, and cooperation.
When the king of the people is able to extensively do such great benefit in the country, he accomplishes two kinds of beneficial matters.
What are the two?
The king is like a parent, loving and caring for all without distinction;
The people of the country are like children, all harboring loyalty and filial piety.
Furthermore, Great King!
Those who become heavenly kings should have a compassionate heart, lightly collecting taxes and reducing corvÃ©e labor;
Establishing officials and dividing their duties, not striving for excessive complexity;
Punishing evil people and promoting the virtuous;
Those who are not loyal and good should be quickly distanced;
Follow the ancient sage kings and do not carry out executions.
Why is this?
Those born in the human realm are moved by superior conditions. If their lives are taken, they will definitely invite evil retribution.
Great King!
You should always single-mindedly respectfully venerate the Three Jewels and do not give rise to wrong views.
After my nirvÄá¹‡a, the Dharma is entrusted to the kings, ministers, and officials. You should protect it and prevent it from declining;
Fan the torch of the true Dharma and turn the wheel of the true Dharma, causing it to be uninterrupted throughout the future.

If you are able to practice in accordance with the teachings like this, it will cause the dragon kings in the country to rejoice, the wind and rain to be in harmony, the gods to be delighted, and there will be abundance, happiness, and peace, with all calamities removed. The whole country will be at peace, and the king's body will be happy. He will forever maintain his superior position, his meritorious power will be extended, he will have no more worries or troubles, his lifespan will be increased, and his fame will be spread throughout the ten directions in the present.
The kings of foreign countries will all praise him, saying:
'The king of such-and-such a country is benevolent, yielding, loyal, and filial. He teaches with the Dharma, rescuing and caring for the common people. He is the foremost among all countries.
We should now all submit to this great Dharma king. After giving up our bodies, we will be reborn in the heavens and receive supreme and wonderful bliss, up to enlightenment!'
Furthermore, great king!
The essence of all dharmas is empty and false, impermanent, decaying, and disintegrating.

It is like a person who, in a dream during the night, sees a beautiful garden, mountains, rivers, people, lush forests, clear springs, halls, and pavilions, all delightful. When they wake up from sleep, not a single thing is seen.
Great king, you should know!

The royal position that is inherited, as well as life, all superior pleasures, sovereignty, nobility, the delights of the five desires, elephants, horses, carriages, infantry, parents, brothers, sons, daughters, queens, all the people of the country, up to ministers and concubines, gold, silver, precious treasures, clothing, food and drink, and all the storehouses, are all abandoned at the end of life.
All these things are impermanent, subject to destruction and decay. They are difficult to preserve, their essence is unstable, and they will eventually be scattered and dispersed;
They are places of fear, able to give rise to suffering and distress, without self or possessions, and also without a master.
One should always contemplate this and not be negligent.
Furthermore, great king!
It is like a large tree, first sprouting leaves and flowers, then bearing fruit. When the fruit is ripe, it gradually falls;
The green leaves turn yellow, and then all fall off, eventually becoming completely exhausted, leaving only an empty tree.
The tree will dry up and be consumed by a great fire, burning fiercely until it is completely destroyed.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!
The sun and moon have great power and abundant light, able to dispel all darkness, but they too will eventually perish.
Your Majesty!
You should contemplate impermanence, non-self, and the matter of destruction, and give rise to fear.
As a king, you should govern with the Dharma and not engage in unrighteousness, always cultivating goodness and not following evil conduct.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!

It is like four great mountains coming from the four directions, solid and compact, without any gaps, rising high into the great void, grinding the earth below, and there is not a single plant, tree, or living creature that can escape them, no strong man can resist them, and there is no way to turn them back with spells, medicine, or wealth.
Great King!
The four mountains in the human world are also like this, namely old age, sickness, death, and loss of power.
Great King!
When old age comes, it makes people wither away;
When sickness strikes, it can cause suffering;
When the time of death arrives, one will surely lose one's life;
When power is lost, it destroys one's authority.
Furthermore, Great King!

Like a lion king, swift and powerful, with sharp claws and teeth, entering a herd of deer, taking whatever it wants to eat, with nothing able to obstruct it, these animals are intimidated by others, having no freedom.
Great King, you should know!
All sentient beings are shot by the arrow of death, having no strength, no refuge, no protection;
When life is about to end, the bones and joints separate, the blood and flesh dry up, the mouth cannot speak, the hands and feet are in disarray, all strength is exhausted;
Saliva, urine, and excrement soil the body, the six sense faculties such as the eyes are all blocked, the breath in the throat is reversed, and food and drink do not pass through;
In each moment, the later consciousness is about to end, and one is carried away by karma, wandering in the ocean of suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death since beginningless time;

At this very moment, when the life force is about to end, all the karmic actions one has done manifest, the messengers of Yama are extremely frightening, and in the long night of darkness, there is no one who can go against them;
The breath of coming and going suddenly ceases, one goes alone without companions, and one is confused about where to go.
Leaving this human world, heading towards the next life, about to fall into a great pit, entering a place of deep darkness;
Only treading on dangerous paths, with no provisions left;
Blown by the winds of karma, not knowing the road ahead, at that time, in distress, with no other refuge, at this time one experiences the results of karma.
Great King!
There is a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« called the Victorious Banner.
If a person has previously received and upheld it, in the cycle of birth and death it can be a good companion, mutually saving and protecting each other.
Great King, listen well!
I will now explain it for you.

like obtaining cool, clear water when it is extremely hot;
like encountering a good tree's shade on a hot summer road;
like encountering a clear spring when thirsty;
like obtaining delicious food when hungry;
like encountering a good doctor when sick and receiving blessed medicine;
like a frightened person obtaining a strong and capable companion.
Great King!
In this way, a person with merit, when about to die, will have auspicious signs leading the way.
Great King!
At this time, only the good Dharma can mutually protect, think of, and take refuge in you. Only this dhÄraá¹‡Ä« can truly rescue and deliver you.
Therefore, Great King!

One should recite this divine mantra every day, able to eliminate all karmic hindrances, and further able to cultivate immeasurable causes of blessings. One should observe that impermanence, destruction, and ultimate emptiness are nonexistent. In the face of death, one should give rise to great fear and transform the world with goodness, not engaging in evil dharmas, always cultivating meritorious deeds, and giving rise to great compassion.
Why is it so?
This body is always cherished and offered with famous delicacies and the finest food and drink. One rests at will according to the season, without worry or constraint.
Although one may experience such supreme bliss, in the end one will not escape the time of death when the fire of hunger comes and one dies of starvation.
Furthermore, great king!
The clothes one wears are all exquisiteâ€”fine linen, white cotton, brocade, gauze, silk, and light and cool fabrics.

Indulging in pleasures according to one's desires, in the end one cannot avoid lying on a bed when facing death, turning over at the mercy of others, filth clinging to the body, bedding and clothing sticking to the body, causing those who see it to feel disgust.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!
In one's lifetime, bathing and adorning the body, applying fragrant powders and various ornaments, incense pervading everywhere, wearing flower garlands on the head.

Even if one enjoys such supreme pleasures, in the end one cannot avoid gradually decaying and returning to one's original form, with foul odors appearing before one, bathing and applying fragrance all becoming pointless.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!
Often staying in the inner palace surrounded by court ladies, with music playing and singing and dancing according to one's feelings.
With pleasure passing the time, not hearing of worries, in the end one cannot avoid the suffering of death coming and being frightened at the end.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!
The palaces they live in are adorned in various ways, with doors and windows that are well-ventilated, keeping the cold and warmth in balance.
They indulge their feelings all day long, enjoying pleasures all night;
In their chambers, bright lamps are lit, with many beautiful women, fragrant incense scattered, and famous flowers spread everywhere;
The beds they sleep on are adorned with the seven treasures, with heavy layers of woolen blankets and pillows, sleeping as they please, without any worries or troubles.
When their karma is exhausted, in the end they cannot escape death. After death, they are sent to the charnel ground, left in the empty wilderness;
The corpses rot and decompose, with pus and blood flowing everywhere;
The bones and flesh are separated, despised by all;
They are eaten by foxes, wolves, owls, and vultures.
Alas, this body!
In the end, it comes to this.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!

On auspicious mornings and festive occasions, the king would adorn his carriage and leave the city, going to fragrant groves to indulge in pleasure and enjoyment. Elephants, horses, carriages, and infantry would accompany him before and after. Those who wished to ride would have their wishes fulfilled. The ministers in attendance would hold peacock fans in proper order, and canopies would be suspended high. They would also hold golden parasols, with music and bells playing in harmony. Everyone would revere him as if he were the Heavenly Emperor Åšakra.
If one's merit and lifespan are exhausted, the messengers of Yama will come to collect one's spirit and bring it before the king. No one can escape the judgment according to one's allotted share.

Only the remaining bones will be left on the ground. Parents, spouse, and the people of the country will all wail in grief, beating their chests in distress. The spirit carriage will be sent to the charnel ground, where the body will be either burned, buried, or submerged in the water. Flying birds, running beasts, fish, turtles, alligators, and otters will smell the flesh and come to feed on it. The bones will become dust, no different from the earth.
Great King, you should know!

All sentient beings who receive consciousness are like this. In the end, they will be destroyed by impermanence. The body is difficult to rely on and believe in. Moment by moment, it changes and shifts. The body of afflictions is not lovable or enjoyable.
Who among the wise would not give rise to disgust and detachment?
Therefore, great king!
You should contemplate this body as the root of suffering, following impermanence, constantly being driven by the king of death.
Knowing this, you should be a Dharma king, and should not indulge in giving rise to greed, anger, and delusion, and engage in evil deeds.
Why is it so?
Great king!

I do not say that there are foolish ordinary beings who, with regard to the five sense objects - form, sound, smell, taste, and touch - always accumulate much, and always enjoy being close to them. Such people are able to give rise to contentment.
Great king!
Who, with regard to sense objects, is able to give rise to a mind of disgust?
It means that when the wise and holy give rise to supreme wisdom and it manifests before them, they will then become content, gradually let go of [attachment], and realize the wonderful nirvana.

At that time, the Heavenly Son of Supreme Light heard the Buddha's explanation, which would bring peace to himself, long preserve his position as king, benefit sentient beings, bring fame to the ten directions, enable him to be reborn in the heavens, and experience supreme bliss.
Deeply rejoicing, having never experienced such a thing before, he joined his palms in respect, single-mindedly gazed up at the Buddha, and said:
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata's great kindness has explained such subtle and wonderful Dharma meanings.
I now accept it on my head and always wish to spread it far and wide, causing all the people of the country to recite and practice it.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Great King!
In your past lives, you cultivated causes and now receive supreme rewards. You have become a heavenly son, and your wishes are fulfilled according to your mind.
You should practice as taught and not be negligent!
At that time, the celestial son of supreme light and the great assembly all greatly rejoiced, believed and accepted, and paid homage to the Buddha before departing.
